channel.title: Losing framerate through dynamic shadows....
channel.description: I have no problems running Half Life - Episode 2 with my Nvidia 8600GT, it runs smooth and im fairly optimistic that Black Mesa will work fine as well ^_^ - except for one little problem...everytime i turn on my flashlight in episode 2, i clearly notice a performance drop, and i know that this is caused by the dynamic shadows. I turned the shadows to medium in the option menu, so the characters wont throw any shadows anymore, and my framerate was a lot better again when i turned my light on. The problem is, i just love those shadows because they create a lot of tense and atmosphere in dark areas. Does anyone know if i can tweak some options so the perfomance loss is not so heavy when the shadows appear, without turning the dynamic shadows completely off?

item.title: Losing framerate through dynamic shadows....
item.dc:creator: yfyitzuydkjvj
item.description:
Evil-Police:

LIES! Kane said the requirements would be similar to TF2.

Nope sorry, the most recent build uses more sophisticated algorithms to procedurally generate raytraced particle shaders. To run the game above 30 fps on medium settings, you will need at least an Nvidia 8800GTX and quad core processor, preferably running 64-bit Windows 7. See below.

Sticky: Updated System Requirements

Read full topic

item.title: Losing framerate through dynamic shadows....
item.dc:creator: sersoft
item.description:
Remove any windows Vista or 7 you might have, and install XP.

Disable themes, disable wallpaper, disable windows update, remove desktop icons, uninstall everything except steam.

I did that (dualboot XP and 7) and I can play games on full settings without any frame drops compared to 10FPS on normal windows 7.

But for source games don’t really matter as none of them ever go below 60fps even on windows 7 for me.

Read full topic

item.title: Losing framerate through dynamic shadows....
item.dc:creator: kechones
item.description:
Anti-aliasing puts a lot of strain on your card, try turning that down.

Other than that look into a new graphics card.

Read full topic

item.title: Losing framerate through dynamic shadows....
item.dc:creator: Xenomorphlover
item.description:
Medevilae:

Yeah, with every setting to the lowest possible.

Do what I told you, set the Direct X level to 8, and then you can set it to the “highest low” settings.

In launch options:

-dxlevel 8

It will look better than the lowest Direct X 9 settings, but obviously not as good as their higher counterparts.

I already tried that out, and everything was faster - but there were no dynamic shadows at all, because it only works with DirectX9!

Read full topic

item.title: Losing framerate through dynamic shadows....
item.dc:creator: Door
item.description:
Mangled*:

I have this card and I don’t experience this problem.

Try these video settings:

https://img405.imageshack.us/img405/3037/ep2settings.jpg

EW EW TRILINEAR FILTERING. EW.
I use AF x4 seeing as it doesn’t actually affect my performance :3

If all else fails, get a new CPU.

Xenomorphlover:

I have no problems running Half Life - Episode 2 with my Nvidia 8600GT, it runs smooth and im fairly optimistic that Black Mesa will work fine as well - except for one little problem…everytime i turn on my flashlight in episode 2, i clearly notice a performance drop, and i know that this is caused by the dynamic shadows. I turned the shadows to medium in the option menu, so the characters wont throw any shadows anymore, and my framerate was a lot better again when i turned my light on. The problem is, i just love those shadows because they create a lot of tense and atmosphere in dark areas.
Does anyone know if i can tweak some options so the perfomance loss is not so heavy when the shadows appear, without turning the dynamic shadows completely off?

I have this card and I don’t experience this problem.

item.title: Losing framerate through dynamic shadows....
item.dc:creator: Door
item.description:
Just really mess around with the settings until you have found what is best for your setup.
If you really want to keep the sexy, dark, mysterious, pure sex dynamic shadows, then turn down your models/textures. It should help improve performance.

I too noticed a drop in performance when turning on the flashlight. The thing I did to stop that from happening was to turn off a few settings in my graphics card control panel :retard:

Read full topic
